Praise be to the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ! In his great mercy he has given us new birth into a living hope through the resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead.

2025-11-21.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the profound truth revealed in 1 Corinthians 15:3-4. We praise you for the death, burial, and resurrection of your Son, Jesus Christ. We are grateful for the sacrifice He made for our sins, and for the hope of eternal life that is ours through Him. Help us to always remember the importance of this message and to share it with others. Grant us faith to believe in the resurrection and to live our lives in light of this glorious truth. Strengthen our resolve to follow Jesus and to live according to your will. Fill us with your Holy Spirit, that we may be witnesses to your saving grace. Thank you for your unwavering love and your promise of everlasting life in your presence. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-11-22.versiculo: Acts 4:12 KJV: "Neither is there salvation in any other: for there is none other name under heaven given among men, whereby we must be saved."
2025-11-22.reflexion: Acts 4:12 is a cornerstone of Christian belief, a bold declaration that salvation is found exclusively in Jesus Christ. This verse resonates with the unwavering conviction of the early church, a conviction that stemmed from their direct experience with the resurrected Christ. They had witnessed His miracles, heard His teachings, and felt the transformative power of His love. This verse doesn't merely suggest a path to salvation; it emphatically states that there is no other. This exclusivity might seem harsh in a world that often celebrates inclusivity and tolerance. However, the Bible's message is not about excluding but about revealing the only source of true and lasting hope. The 'name' referred to is not simply a label, but the person, the character, and the work of Jesus. It encapsulates His life, death, and resurrection, all offered for the redemption of humanity. This verse challenges us to examine our own beliefs and where we place our trust. Are we placing our hope in worldly things, in our own efforts, or in the unwavering promise of salvation through Christ? Embracing this truth demands a level of faith, a recognition of our need for a Savior, and a willingness to surrender to His Lordship.

para_meditar.texto: Jesus saith unto him, I am the way, the truth, and the life: no man cometh unto the Father, but by me.

That if thou shalt confess with thy mouth the Lord Jesus, and shalt believe in thine heart that God hath raised him from the dead, thou shalt be saved. For with the heart man believeth unto righteousness; and with the mouth confession is made unto salvation.
For there is one God, and one mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus;

2025-11-22.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you with hearts full of gratitude for the gift of salvation through Jesus Christ. We acknowledge that He is the only way to eternal life, the only name by which we can be saved. Lord, help us to live out this truth in our daily lives, to proclaim the good news of Jesus to all we encounter. Give us the courage to stand firm in our faith, even when faced with opposition. Help us to rely on Your strength, to trust in Your promises, and to always seek Your will. Fill us with Your Holy Spirit, that we may be bold witnesses for You, sharing the hope and love of Jesus with the world. Thank you for the ultimate sacrifice of Your Son. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-11-23.versiculo: Matthew 19:26 NIV2011: "Jesus looked at them and said, “With man this is impossible, but with God all things are possible.”"
2025-11-23.reflexion: Matthew 19:26 encapsulates a profound truth about the nature of faith and the limitless power of God. The context of this verse is the discussion about the difficulty of the rich entering the kingdom of heaven. Jesus' disciples were astonished, wondering who then could be saved. Jesus' response highlights the fundamental difference between human limitations and divine capabilities. We often struggle with challenges that seem insurmountable. We look at our circumstances, our abilities, and our resources and conclude that certain things are simply impossible. This verse reminds us that our human perspective is narrow. We see only the surface, the immediate obstacles. God, however, sees the whole picture. He sees the potential, the possibilities beyond our comprehension. He can work in ways we cannot imagine, using resources we don't even know exist. This truth is not merely a comforting thought; it's a call to action. It's an invitation to trust in God's power, even when the odds seem stacked against us. It's a challenge to release our anxieties and embrace the belief that, with God, all things are possible. This requires a shift in perspective, a willingness to surrender control, and a deep, unwavering faith in the character and promises of God.

para_meditar.texto: I can do all things through Christ who strengthens me.
Ah, Sovereign Lord, you have made the heavens and the earth by your great power and outstretched arm. Nothing is too hard for you.
Jesus looked at them and said, “With man this is impossible, but not with God. For all things are possible with God.”

2025-11-23.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today acknowledging our limitations and the challenges that often overwhelm us. We confess that we often rely on our own strength and understanding, forgetting the vastness of your power. We thank you for the reminder in Matthew 19:26 that with you, all things are possible. Help us to release our fears and anxieties, and to trust in your divine ability to work in ways we cannot fathom. Grant us the faith to believe that you are able to overcome every obstacle and fulfill your purposes in our lives. Give us the courage to step out in faith, knowing that you are with us, empowering us. Guide us to seek your will and to surrender our lives completely to your care. Fill us with your Holy Spirit so that we may experience your power and grace in every area of our lives. We pray for a renewed sense of hope and confidence in your unwavering love and faithfulness, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-11-24.versiculo: Mark 14:36 NIV: ""Abba, Father," he said, "everything is possible for you. Take this cup from me. Yet not what I will, but what you will."
2025-11-24.reflexion: Mark 14:36 presents a profound moment of vulnerability and submission in the Garden of Gethsemane. Jesus, facing the immeasurable weight of the cross, acknowledges the Father's power while simultaneously expressing his own human desire to avoid suffering. The phrase "Abba, Father," reveals an intimate relationship, a filial bond of love and trust. Jesus doesn't begin with a demand, but with a plea, recognizing God’s omnipotence; "everything is possible for you." He acknowledges that God can change the course of events. However, even in this moment of anguish, Jesus prioritizes God's will above his own. This is the essence of true faith: to seek God's plan, even when it leads to pain or uncertainty. The prayer teaches us that prayer is not just about asking for what we want, but about aligning our hearts with God's will. It's about trusting in His wisdom, even when we don't understand. It encourages us to embrace our fears, and to be willing to surrender our own desires to the greater purposes of God, knowing that He is in control and that He loves us perfectly.

para_meditar.texto: Trust in the Lord with all your heart and lean not on your own understanding; in all your ways submit to him, and he will make your paths straight.
And being found in appearance as a man, he humbled himself by becoming obedient to death—even death on a cross!
And we know that in all things God works for the good of those who love him, who have been called according to his purpose.

2025-11-24.oracion: Heavenly Father, like Jesus in the Garden of Gethsemane, I come before you with a heavy heart. I acknowledge your power and your ability to do all things. I lift up my worries, my fears, and my desires to you. Help me to trust in your plan, even when I don't understand it. Grant me the strength to surrender my will to yours, knowing that you love me and that you work all things for good. Give me the courage to embrace the challenges before me and to remain steadfast in my faith. Help me to remember that you are always with me, guiding me and protecting me. I pray that my life may be a testament to your glory and a reflection of your love. Guide me to find peace in your will, and to find strength in your presence. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-11-25.versiculo: 2 Thessalonians 3:10 KJV: "For even when we were with you, this we commanded you, that if any would not work, neither should he eat."
2025-11-25.reflexion: Today's verse from 2 Thessalonians 3:10, "For even when we were with you, this we commanded you, that if any would not work, neither should he eat," speaks to the fundamental dignity of labor and the importance of self-sufficiency within the Christian community. This wasn't just a suggestion from Paul; it was a command. He emphasized that idleness was not to be tolerated, especially within a fellowship that was intended to be a model of righteousness and productivity. The principle is clear: work is a necessary component of a healthy life, both physically and spiritually. It is a call to responsibility, a warning against taking advantage of others, and a reminder of the value of contributing to the common good. Paul’s words resonate even today, challenging us to examine our own work ethic and our attitudes toward those who are able but unwilling to contribute. It's a call to action, urging us to be diligent in our tasks, to contribute to society, and to find fulfillment in the work we do, understanding that our labor is a reflection of our faith.

para_meditar.texto: In all labor there is profit: but the talk of the lips tendeth only to penury.
Let him that stole steal no more: but rather let him labour, working with his hands the thing which is good, that he may have to give to him that needeth.
And whatsoever ye do, do it heartily, as to the Lord, and not unto men;

2025-11-25.oracion: Heavenly Father, we thank You for the gift of work and for the opportunity to contribute to Your kingdom. We are grateful for the strength and abilities You have given us. We pray for diligence and a good work ethic in all that we do, and help us to avoid laziness and idleness. Help us to be responsible and productive members of society, and to use our talents to serve others. Guide us to find satisfaction in our work and to remember that our labor is a reflection of our faith. Help us to be generous with what we earn and to share with those in need. Give us the wisdom to manage our time and resources wisely. We commit our work to You, trusting that You will bless our efforts. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-11-26.versiculo: Revelation 3:16 KJV: "So then because thou art lukewarm, and neither cold nor hot, I will spue thee out of my mouth."
2025-11-26.reflexion: Today's verse from Revelation 3:16 offers a stark warning about spiritual indifference. Jesus's words to the church of Laodicea paint a picture of a people who are neither passionately devoted to Him nor actively rejecting Him. They are lukewarm, and this tepidness is met with a strong reaction: Jesus says He will 'spue' them out of His mouth. This imagery is powerful and unsettling, highlighting the distaste God has for a faith that is half-hearted and lacks genuine zeal. The Laodiceans, though wealthy and self-sufficient, were spiritually impoverished. They were blind to their true condition, believing they were in need of nothing. This verse challenges us to examine the temperature of our own faith. Are we truly burning with a love for God, or have we become complacent, allowing the busyness of life to dilute our devotion? Are we actively seeking to grow closer to Him, or are we content with a superficial relationship? The call here is to be either hot or cold – to make a decisive choice, to embrace a faith that is vibrant and alive. Lukewarm faith is not just ineffective; it is repulsive to God. Let us strive for a faith that is fervent, passionate, and actively engaged in living out the Gospel.

para_meditar.texto: Not slothful in business; fervent in spirit; serving the Lord.
No man can serve two masters: for either he will hate the one, and love the other; or else he will hold to the one, and despise the other. Ye cannot serve God and mammon.
Draw nigh to God, and he will draw nigh to you. Cleanse your hands, ye sinners; and purify your hearts, ye double minded.

2025-11-26.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today with a humble heart, seeking to examine the temperature of my faith. I confess that I often fall short, allowing the distractions of the world to cool my zeal for You. Forgive me for the times when I am lukewarm, when my heart is not fully devoted to You. Help me to cultivate a passionate love for You, to be fervent in spirit, and to serve You with all my heart, soul, and mind. Grant me the wisdom to discern the things that hinder my relationship with You and the strength to overcome them. Fill me with Your Holy Spirit, that I may be a vessel of Your love and grace. Guide me to live a life that is pleasing in Your sight, a life that is truly hot for You, a life that glorifies Your name. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-11-27.versiculo: 1 John 3:1 KJV: "Behold, what manner of love the Father hath bestowed upon us, that we should be called the sons of God: therefore the world knoweth us not, because it knew him not."
2025-11-27.reflexion: 1 John 3:1 unveils a profound truth about our identity and the immeasurable love God has for us. It calls us to pause and consider the sheer magnitude of the Father's love, a love so vast that He calls us His children. This isn't a casual acknowledgment; it's a declaration of adoption, a familial bond that transcends our earthly existence. The verse highlights the contrast between our new identity in Christ and the world's perception of us. Because the world does not know God, it cannot comprehend the love He has for us, nor can it recognize our transformed state. This leads to a sense of alienation, but it is an alienation born of our belonging to a higher kingdom, a realm of love and grace. We are set apart, not in arrogance, but in the simple reality of our relationship with the Almighty. The implications of this truth are numerous: we are heirs, we are loved unconditionally, and we have a purpose that transcends the limitations of the world. Understanding this allows us to approach life with confidence, knowing that we are deeply loved and intimately connected to the source of all goodness. We are called to live as children of God, reflecting His love and grace in all we do.

para_meditar.texto: The Spirit itself beareth witness with our spirit, that we are the children of God.
And because ye are sons, God hath sent forth the Spirit of his Son into your hearts, crying, Abba, Father.
Having predestinated us unto the adoption of children by Jesus Christ to himself, according to the good pleasure of his will,

2025-11-27.oracion: Heavenly Father, we stand in awe of Your boundless love, a love so great that You call us Your children. Help us to truly grasp the depth of this incredible gift, that we might live each day with renewed gratitude and purpose. Grant us the discernment to see ourselves as You see us, to recognize our identity in Christ, and to walk in the light of Your love. Shield us from the world's confusion and help us to reflect Your character in all that we do. Guide us to live lives worthy of the title of sons and daughters, filled with love, compassion, and grace, so that others may see You in us. Strengthen our faith, deepen our understanding, and fill us with Your peace. Help us to share the good news of Your love and grace with all those we encounter, so that they too may know the joy of being Your children. in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-11-28.versiculo: Revelation 4:8 KJV: "And the four beasts had each of them six wings about him; and they were full of eyes within: and they rest not day and night, saying, Holy, holy, holy, Lord God Almighty, which was, and is, and is to come."
2025-11-28.reflexion: Revelation 4:8 offers a glimpse into the ceaseless worship of God in heaven. The four living creatures, described as having six wings and being covered with eyes, constantly proclaim God's holiness. This verse paints a picture of a constant, unwavering focus on God's character and attributes. The repetition of "holy, holy, holy" emphasizes the absolute purity, majesty, and transcendence of God. It is a recognition that God is set apart, distinct, and worthy of all worship. These creatures, representing all of creation, never cease their praise, a testament to the overwhelming glory of God. Their declaration is a reminder that worship isn't just a Sunday activity; it is a continuous state of being, a constant awareness of God's presence and goodness. We are called to emulate this, to cultivate a heart that is perpetually aware of God's holiness and to live in a manner that reflects His glory. The description of God as "Lord God Almighty, which was, and is, and is to come" further underscores His eternal nature and sovereignty over all of time and creation. This should inspire us to worship Him with reverence and awe.

para_meditar.texto: Give unto the Lord the glory due unto his name; worship the Lord in the beauty of holiness.
And one cried unto another, and said, Holy, holy, holy, is the Lord of hosts: the whole earth is full of his glory.
God is a Spirit: and they that worship him must worship him in spirit and in truth.

2025-11-28.oracion: Heavenly Father, we are humbled by the vision of your endless glory and the constant worship offered to you in heaven. We are inspired by the living creatures who never cease to proclaim your holiness. Help us to cultivate a heart that is constantly aware of your presence and goodness. Grant us the ability to see you in every aspect of our lives, to recognize your majesty in the beauty of creation, and to worship you with reverence and awe. Help us to live lives that reflect your glory, and to offer you praise not just in moments of worship, but in every thought, word, and deed. Guide us to be a people of prayer, constantly seeking your will and giving thanks for your blessings. Fill us with a deep desire to know you more, to love you more, and to serve you more faithfully. We ask all these things, trusting in your perfect love and grace, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-11-29.versiculo: Acts 13:38-39 KJV: "Be it known unto you therefore, men and brethren, that through this man is preached unto you the forgiveness of sins: And by him all that believe are justified from all things, from which ye could not be justified by the law of Moses."
2025-11-29.reflexion: In Acts 13:38-39, Paul delivers a powerful message of grace and freedom. He proclaims that forgiveness of sins is available through Jesus Christ. This isn't just a partial forgiveness; it's a complete justification from all things. The law, though important in its time, could not provide this complete cleansing. It revealed sin but couldn't erase it. This passage highlights the transformative power of faith. It emphasizes that belief in Jesus is the key to receiving forgiveness and being declared righteous in God's eyes. This is a gift, not something earned. We are justified, not by our own works, but by the finished work of Christ on the cross. This justification is a declaration of innocence, a release from the guilt and penalty of sin. It means a new beginning, a restored relationship with God. It’s a call to embrace the freedom that comes with knowing our sins are forgiven and we are made new in Christ. The power of the Gospel resides in this core truth: we are not condemned, but redeemed.

para_meditar.texto: There is therefore now no condemnation to them which are in Christ Jesus, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit.

Knowing that a man is not justified by the works of the law, but by the faith of Jesus Christ, even we have believed in Jesus Christ, that we might be justified by the faith of Christ, and not by the works of the law: for by the works of the law shall no flesh be justified.
For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God: Not of works, lest any man should boast.

2025-11-29.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the incredible gift of forgiveness found in Jesus Christ. Thank you that through His sacrifice, I am justified and made righteous in Your eyes. Help me to live in the freedom of this truth, knowing that I am no longer condemned but redeemed. Grant me the grace to continually embrace Your love and mercy. Help me to trust in Your promises and to walk in the light of Your truth, leaving behind the burden of sin. Give me the strength to share this good news with others, that they too may experience the joy of forgiveness and the peace of knowing You. Guide me to live a life worthy of this grace, filled with love, compassion, and service to others. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-11-30.versiculo: 1 Corinthians 3:16 NIV: "Don’t you know that you yourselves are God’s temple and that God’s Spirit dwells in your midst?"
2025-11-30.reflexion:
Today's verse reminds us of a profound truth: we are the temple of God. This isn't just a poetic statement; it's a declaration of our inherent value and the sacredness of our lives. The Holy Spirit, the very presence of God, resides within us. This understanding transforms how we view ourselves and how we live. We are no longer just individuals; we are dwelling places of the divine.  

This verse calls us to recognize the dignity and sanctity within us. It challenges us to treat our bodies, our minds, and our spirits with the utmost care and respect, as we would a sacred space.  We are called to live in a manner worthy of the Spirit that dwells within. This includes making choices that reflect God's love, grace, and truth. It means avoiding things that defile the temple – sin, negativity, and harmful influences.  

Furthermore, the fact that God's Spirit dwells 'in your midst' implies a collective responsibility. We, as the body of Christ, are also a temple. We are called to build each other up, to encourage one another, and to create a community where the Spirit can thrive. Let us reflect on our lives as temples, and strive to live in a way that honors the Holy Spirit dwelling within us and amongst us.

para_meditar.texto: You, however, are not in the realm of the flesh but are in the realm of the Spirit, if indeed the Spirit of God lives in you. And if anyone does not have the Spirit of Christ, they do not belong to Christ.
But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, forbearance, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness and self-control. Against such things there is no law.
And in him you too are being built together to become a dwelling in which God lives by his Spirit.

2025-11-30.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the incredible privilege of being a temple of the Holy Spirit. Thank you for dwelling within me, guiding me, and empowering me to live a life that reflects your love and grace. Help me to recognize the sacredness within myself and within my brothers and sisters in Christ. Grant me the strength to resist temptation and to make choices that honor you. Help me to cultivate the fruit of the Spirit in my life: love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, and self-control. Give me a heart that is always open to your leading and a mind that is focused on your truth. Help me to build up the church, the collective temple, with love and unity.  I surrender my life to you, seeking to live in a manner worthy of the Spirit that dwells within. in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-01.versiculo: Hebrews 13:15-16 KJV: "By him therefore let us offer the sacrifice of praise to God continually, that is, the fruit of our lips giving thanks to his name. But to do good and to communicate forget not: for with such sacrifices God is pleased."
2025-12-01.reflexion: Today's verses from Hebrews 13 call us to a life of continuous praise and practical acts of love. The "sacrifice of praise" is not merely a Sunday morning ritual; it's an ongoing offering, the fruit of our lips giving thanks to His name. This means that every word we speak, every thought we entertain, should be seasoned with gratitude and acknowledgment of God's goodness. But praise isn't enough. The passage immediately connects this with "doing good" and "communicating," which means sharing with those in need. This isn't just about giving money, but also about sharing our time, our talents, and our love. It's about being present in the lives of others and meeting their needs, both physical and spiritual. The verse tells us that these actions are pleasing to God. It's not just about what we say, but about how we live. Our lives become a living sacrifice of praise when we actively seek to do good and share with others. This is a beautiful picture of a faith that is both inward and outward, a faith that transforms both our hearts and our world.

para_meditar.texto: Enter into his gates with thanksgiving, and into his courts with praise: be thankful unto him, and bless his name.
As we have therefore opportunity, let us do good unto all men, especially unto them who are of the household of faith.

What doth it profit, my brethren, though a man say he hath faith, and have not works? can faith save him? If a brother or sister be naked, and destitute of daily food, And one of you say unto them, Depart in peace, be ye warmed and filled; notwithstanding ye give them not those things which are needful to the body; what doth it profit? Even so faith, if it hath not works, is dead, being alone.

2025-12-01.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the gift of life and for the opportunity to praise your holy name. Help me to make my words a continual offering of gratitude, always acknowledging your grace and mercy in my life. Guide me to see the needs of those around me, and grant me the compassion and resources to meet those needs. Give me the strength to do good, to share generously, and to live a life that reflects your love. May my actions be a testament to my faith, bringing glory to your name. Help me to remember that true worship is not just in my heart, but in my actions. Help me to make my life a sacrifice of praise, always striving to live in a way that is pleasing to you, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-02.versiculo: Jude 1:24-25 NIV: "To him who is able to keep you from stumbling and to present you before his glorious presence without fault and with great joy— to the only God our Savior be glory, majesty, power and authority, through Jesus Christ our Lord, before all ages, now and forevermore! Amen."
2025-12-02.reflexion: Jude's doxology in verses 24-25 is a powerful declaration of God's ability to keep us from stumbling and present us blameless before Him. It's a reminder that our salvation isn't solely dependent on our own efforts, but on the power of God. We are prone to stumble; life throws curveballs, temptations abound, and our own weaknesses often lead us astray. But God, in His infinite grace, is able to protect us. He doesn't just keep us from falling; He presents us before His glorious presence, not with shame or condemnation, but with joy. This is a testament to His faithfulness and love. The passage focuses on God's power and His role as our Savior. The glory, majesty, power, and authority belong to Him, not just for a season, but before all ages, now and forevermore. This eternal perspective offers comfort and hope, reminding us that our struggles are temporary, and our ultimate reward is an eternity spent in the presence of our loving God, through Jesus Christ. This passage empowers us to trust in God's unwavering ability to protect and guide us, to embrace His grace, and to live with the joyful anticipation of our eternal home.

para_meditar.texto: He will not let your foot slip— he who watches over you will not slumber.

For I am convinced that neither death nor life, neither angels nor demons, neither the present nor the future, nor any powers, neither height nor depth, nor anything else in all creation, will be able to separate us from the love of God that is in Christ Jesus our Lord.
being confident of this, that he who began a good work in you will carry it on to completion until the day of Christ Jesus.

2025-12-02.oracion: Dear Heavenly Father, we come before You today with hearts full of gratitude for Your unwavering love and protection. We acknowledge our weaknesses and our propensity to stumble, but we also recognize Your incredible power to keep us from falling. Thank You for Your grace, which covers our sins and allows us to stand before You without fault. We praise You for Your glory, majesty, power, and authority, which are eternal. Help us to trust in Your ability to guide us through the trials of life and to live with the joyful anticipation of our eternal home with You. Grant us the strength to resist temptation and to remain steadfast in our faith, knowing that You are always with us. We commit our lives to You, seeking to honor You in all that we do, now and forever. We give You all the praise and glory, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-03.versiculo: Matthew 13:3-9 KJV: "And he spake many things unto them in parables, saying, Behold, a sower went forth to sow; And when he sowed, some seeds fell by the way side, and the fowls came and devoured them up: Some fell upon stony places, where they had not much earth: and forthwith they sprung up, because they had no deepness of earth: And when the sun was up, they were scorched; and because they had no root, they withered away. And some fell among thorns; and the thorns sprung up, and choked them: But other fell into good ground, and brought forth fruit, some an hundredfold, some sixtyfold, some thirtyfold. Who hath ears to hear, let him hear."
2025-12-03.reflexion: The parable of the sower in Matthew 13:3-9 is a powerful illustration of the various responses people have to the Word of God. The sower represents Jesus, and the seed is the gospel message. The different types of soil represent the different conditions of human hearts. The seed that falls by the wayside represents those who hear the Word but do not understand it, and the enemy (Satan) snatches it away. The seed that falls on stony ground represents those who receive the Word with joy but have no root, and when trials come, they fall away. The seed that falls among thorns represents those who hear the Word but are choked by the cares of this world and the deceitfulness of riches. Finally, the seed that falls on good ground represents those who hear the Word, understand it, and bear fruit, some a hundredfold, some sixtyfold, and some thirtyfold. This parable challenges us to examine the condition of our own hearts. Are we receptive to the Word of God? Are we allowing the cares of the world to choke the seed? Or are we striving to be good soil, bearing fruit for the Kingdom of God? The key to understanding this parable is to have 'ears to hear,' that is, to be open and receptive to the teachings of Jesus.

para_meditar.texto: The sower soweth the word.
And other fell on good ground, and sprang up, and bare fruit an hundredfold. And when he had said these things, he cried, He that hath ears to hear, let him hear.

For the word of God is quick, and powerful, and sharper than any twoedged sword, piercing even to the dividing asunder of soul and spirit, and of the joints and marrow, and is a discerner of the thoughts and intents of the heart.

2025-12-03.oracion: Lord, help me to be good soil, receptive to Your Word. Remove the hard places in my heart, the stony places, and the thorny places that prevent Your Word from taking root and bearing fruit in my life. Grant me understanding to comprehend the truths of Your Gospel. Help me to be diligent in studying Your Word, meditating on it day and night. Give me the strength to resist the temptations and distractions of the world that seek to choke out Your Word. Open my ears to hear Your voice and my heart to receive Your message. Help me to bear fruit, bringing glory to Your name and impacting the lives of others. Thank You for the gift of Your Word. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-04.versiculo: Matthew 3:16-17 KJV: "And Jesus, when he was baptized, went up straightway out of the water: and, lo, the heavens were opened unto him, and he saw the Spirit of God descending like a dove, and lighting upon him: And lo a voice from heaven, saying, This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased."
2025-12-04.reflexion:
Today's passage from Matthew paints a powerful picture of God's affirmation of Jesus. The baptism of Jesus marks a pivotal moment, a public declaration of His identity and purpose. As Jesus emerges from the water, the heavens open, the Spirit descends like a dove, and God's voice booms, proclaiming, "This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased." This scene is rich with symbolism. The opening of the heavens signifies a connection between the earthly and the divine. The Spirit's descent illustrates the Holy Spirit's anointing and empowerment of Jesus for His ministry. The Father's declaration is a testament to Jesus' divine nature and His role as the Messiah.

This passage reminds us of our own baptisms, if we have been baptized. Just as God affirmed Jesus, He also affirms us when we choose to follow Him. We too are beloved children, accepted and loved by the Father. The Holy Spirit, like the dove, comes to dwell within us, empowering us to live lives that honor God. Let us remember this day, and every day, that we are loved, chosen, and empowered to live in accordance with His will. Let us strive to hear the voice of God in our lives, guiding us, comforting us, and leading us to a deeper relationship with Him.

para_meditar.texto: Behold my servant, whom I uphold; mine elect, in whom my soul delighteth; I have put my spirit upon him: he shall bring forth judgment to the Gentiles.
And John bare record, saying, I saw the Spirit descending from heaven like a dove, and it abode upon him.
The Spirit itself beareth witness with our spirit, that we are the children of God:

2025-12-04.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the beautiful picture of your love and affirmation presented in Matthew 3:16-17. Thank you for sending your Son, Jesus, to be baptized and to begin His ministry. Thank you for the Holy Spirit, who empowers and guides us. Help us to remember that we are your beloved children, and that you are well pleased with us. Grant us the grace to live lives that reflect your love and to hear your voice guiding us daily. Help us to be receptive to the Holy Spirit's leading, to embrace your will for our lives, and to share your love with others. Let your peace and joy fill our hearts, and let our lives be a testament to your glory. We ask all this, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-05.versiculo: Matthew 6:9-13 NIV: "“This, then, is how you should pray: “‘Our Father in heaven, hallowed be your name, your kingdom come, your will be done, on earth as it is in heaven. Give us today our daily bread. And forgive us our debts, as we also have forgiven our debtors. And lead us not into temptation, but deliver us from the evil one.’"
2025-12-05.reflexion: Today's passage, the Lord's Prayer, is more than just a recitation; it's a model for our relationship with God. It begins with acknowledging God's holiness and sovereignty – 'Our Father in heaven, hallowed be your name.' This sets the tone, reminding us that we approach a majestic and loving God. We then pray for His kingdom to come and His will to be done, reflecting a desire to align our lives with His purposes. The prayer then shifts to our needs: daily provision, forgiveness, and protection from temptation. This highlights the balance between seeking God's will and acknowledging our dependence on Him. The inclusion of forgiving others is crucial; it underscores the importance of extending the same grace we receive. Finally, we ask for deliverance from evil, recognizing the spiritual battle we face and the need for God's protection. This prayer is a blueprint for a life of faith, humility, and dependence on God, reminding us to prioritize His will and trust in His provision.

para_meditar.texto: Do not be anxious about anything, but in every situation, by prayer and petition, with thanksgiving, present your requests to God.
He says, “Be still, and know that I am God; I will be exalted among the nations, I will be exalted in the earth.”
If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just and will forgive us our sins and purify us from all unrighteousness.

2025-12-05.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for teaching us how to pray. We praise your holy name and long for your kingdom to come. Help us to align our hearts and actions with your will, just as it is in heaven. We humbly ask for our daily provision, and we thank you for your abundant blessings. Forgive us our sins, as we forgive those who sin against us. Protect us from temptation and deliver us from the evil one. Guide us to a life of faith, love, and obedience, reflecting your grace and mercy in all we do. We commit our lives to you, trusting in your unwavering love and guidance, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-06.versiculo: Hebrews 4:14-16 NIV: "Therefore, since we have a great high priest who has ascended into heaven, Jesus the Son of God, let us hold firmly to the faith we profess. For we do not have a high priest who is unable to empathize with our weaknesses, but we have one who has been tempted in every way, just as we are—yet he did not sin. Let us then approach God’s throne of grace with confidence, so that we may receive mercy and find grace to help us in our time of need."
2025-12-06.reflexion: Today's passage in Hebrews 4:14-16 offers profound comfort and encouragement. It reminds us that we have a High Priest, Jesus, who has ascended into heaven and sits at the right hand of God. This is not just any priest; it is the Son of God. Because of this, we are called to hold firmly to our faith. The passage further assures us that Jesus understands our struggles. He was tempted in every way, yet remained without sin. This is crucial because it means He can empathize with our weaknesses. He understands what it's like to face trials, temptations, and the complexities of human life. Therefore, we are invited to approach God's throne of grace with boldness and confidence. We don't need to be afraid or ashamed. Instead, we can come knowing that we will receive mercy and grace to help us in our time of need. This grace is not just for salvation, but for our daily lives, providing strength and support in our moments of weakness and need. It's a call to trust in Jesus, our empathetic High Priest, and to seek His help without hesitation.

para_meditar.texto: But God demonstrates his own love for us in this: While we were still sinners, Christ died for us.
So do not fear, for I am with you; do not be dismayed, for I am your God. I will strengthen you and help you; I will uphold you with my righteous right hand.
Do not be anxious about anything, but in every situation, by prayer and petition, with thanksgiving, present your requests to God.

2025-12-06.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the gift of Jesus, our High Priest, who understands our weaknesses and temptations. Thank you that we can approach your throne of grace with confidence, knowing we will receive mercy and grace in our time of need. Help us to hold firmly to our faith, to trust in your love, and to seek your guidance in every aspect of our lives. Grant us the strength to resist temptation and the wisdom to make choices that honor you. Fill us with your peace that surpasses all understanding. Help us to remember that we are never alone, that you are always with us, ready to help. We pray for those who are struggling, those who are facing trials, and those who need your comfort and support. Guide them and give them strength. We ask all this, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-07.versiculo: 2 Timothy 1:9 KJV: "Who hath saved us, and called us with an holy calling, not according to our works, but according to his own purpose and grace, which was given us in Christ Jesus before the world began,"
2025-12-07.reflexion: Today's verse, 2 Timothy 1:9, is a powerful reminder of God's initiative in our salvation. It emphasizes that our calling to holiness isn't based on our performance or merit, but on God's own purpose and grace. This grace was given to us in Christ Jesus before the very foundation of the world. This pre-ordained plan speaks volumes about God's love and foreknowledge. It highlights that salvation is not something we earn, but a gift freely offered through Christ. We were chosen and called, not because of anything we did, but because of God's eternal plan. This should fill us with immense gratitude and humility. It should also inspire us to live lives worthy of this calling. Understanding the depths of this grace empowers us to embrace our identity in Christ and to live with confidence, knowing we are secure in His love and purpose. The verse encourages us to reflect on the magnitude of God's plan and the profound implications of His grace in our lives, urging us to live a life that reflects this incredible gift.

para_meditar.texto: According as he hath chosen us in him before the foundation of the world, that we should be holy and without blame before him in love:
And we know that all things work together for good to them that love God, to them who are the called according to his purpose.
Not by works of righteousness which we have done, but according to his mercy he saved us, by the washing of regeneration, and renewing of the Holy Ghost;

2025-12-07.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for your immeasurable grace, which you bestowed upon us through Christ Jesus before the world began. Thank you for calling us with a holy calling, not according to our works, but according to your own purpose. Help us to understand the depth of your love and the magnitude of your sacrifice. Grant us the wisdom to live lives worthy of this calling, reflecting your grace in all that we do. Give us the strength to resist the temptations of this world and to walk in the path of righteousness. May we always remember that our salvation is a gift, not an achievement, and may we be filled with gratitude for the undeserved favor you have shown us. Help us to embrace our identity in Christ and to live with confidence in your eternal purpose for our lives. Help us to be a beacon of light, reflecting your love to all those around us. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-08.versiculo: Revelation 7:16-17 KJV: "They shall hunger no more, neither thirst any more; neither shall the sun light on them, nor any heat. For the Lamb which is in the midst of the throne shall feed them, and shall lead them unto living fountains of waters: and God shall wipe away all tears from their eyes."
2025-12-08.reflexion: This passage from Revelation paints a vivid picture of the ultimate rest and comfort awaiting believers in eternity. The imagery of no more hunger, thirst, or scorching heat speaks to the complete cessation of suffering. The sun, a source of both life and potential hardship, will no longer be a threat. Instead, the Lamb, Jesus Christ, is at the center, providing nourishment and guidance. He will lead them to "living fountains of waters," a symbol of eternal life and refreshment. The most poignant promise is that God Himself will "wipe away all tears." This signifies the end of sorrow, pain, and all forms of suffering. It's a promise of complete restoration and a deep intimacy with God. This vision of heaven is not just a place of physical comfort; it's a place of profound spiritual and emotional healing. It's a place where the deepest longings of the human heart are finally and fully satisfied in the presence of the Lamb and the Father. This gives us hope to persevere through the trials of this life, knowing that our ultimate reward is a life of unending joy and peace.

para_meditar.texto: He will swallow up death forever; and the Lord God will wipe away tears from all faces, and the reproach of his people he will take away from all the earth, for the Lord has spoken.

In my Father's house are many rooms. If it were not so, would I have told you that I go to prepare a place for you? And if I go and prepare a place for you, I will come again and will take you to myself, that where I am you may be also.
For I consider that the sufferings of this present time are not worth comparing with the glory that is to be revealed to us.

2025-12-08.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the beautiful promise of Revelation 7:16-17. Thank you for the assurance that in your presence, we will experience no more suffering, hunger, or thirst. Thank you for the promise of the Lamb who will feed us and guide us to living waters. Lord, wipe away the tears of sorrow and pain that we experience in this life. Help us to fix our eyes on the eternal hope that awaits us, and to live lives of faith and obedience. Grant us strength to endure the trials of this world, knowing that our reward is great in Heaven. Fill us with your peace and comfort, and remind us daily of your unwavering love. Guide us to share this hope with others, so that they too may find solace in your promises. We give you all the glory and praise, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-09.versiculo: Galatians 5:1 KJV: "Stand fast therefore in the liberty wherewith Christ hath made us free, and be not entangled again with the yoke of bondage."
2025-12-09.reflexion: Galatians 5:1 is a resounding call to freedom! Paul urges believers to stand firm in the liberty Christ has won for us. This freedom is not just a release from the penalty of sin, but also a liberation from the controlling power of sin and the legalistic yoke of the Law. The verse emphasizes the ongoing nature of this freedom; we are to *stand fast*. This implies a constant vigilance, a determination to resist any attempt to be re-enslaved. The 'yoke of bondage' refers to any system or ideology that seeks to control or restrict our relationship with God. This could be legalism, where we try to earn God's favor through works, or other forms of spiritual bondage. The key is Christ. He is the source of our freedom, and through faith in Him, we are set free. This freedom is not an excuse for sin, but an opportunity to live a life pleasing to God, empowered by the Holy Spirit. It is a freedom to serve, to love, and to live abundantly. We must continually remind ourselves of the price Jesus paid for our freedom and strive to live in the fullness of it every day. It is a daily choice, a decision to resist the chains of the past and embrace the glorious liberty we have in Christ.

para_meditar.texto: If the Son therefore shall make you free, ye shall be free indeed.
For the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus hath made me free from the law of sin and death.
Now the Lord is that Spirit: and where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty.

2025-12-09.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the incredible gift of freedom through Jesus Christ. Thank you for breaking the chains of sin and the yoke of bondage that once held me captive. Help me to stand firm in the liberty You have given me, and to resist any temptation to return to the old ways. Grant me the strength to live a life that honors You, guided by the Holy Spirit. Help me to understand the true meaning of freedom and to use it to serve You and love others. Give me the wisdom to discern the things that try to enslave me, and the courage to break free from them. Fill me with Your peace and joy, as I walk in the freedom You have provided. I pray for the strength to remain steadfast in my faith, and to share the good news of freedom with others. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-10.versiculo: Romans 3:23 KJV: "For all have sinned, and come short of the glory of God."
2025-12-10.reflexion: Today's verse, Romans 3:23, is a stark yet essential truth. It cuts through any illusions of inherent goodness and reminds us that every single person, without exception, has fallen short. The phrase "all have sinned" is a universal indictment. It levels the playing field, revealing that we are all on the same ground: in need of grace. The second part of the verse, "and come short of the glory of God," paints a picture of the ultimate consequence. We are separated from the radiant presence of God. We miss the mark, failing to live up to the perfect standard He sets. This understanding is not meant to condemn us, but to humble us. It's a starting point, the foundation upon which the good news of the Gospel is built. Recognizing our sinfulness allows us to grasp the magnitude of God's love and the sacrifice of Jesus Christ. It highlights the necessity of His grace and the transformative power of His forgiveness. This verse is not a dead end, but an open door. It is an invitation to turn away from our sin and toward the source of true glory: God Himself.

para_meditar.texto: But we are all as an unclean thing, and all our righteousnesses are as filthy rags; and we all do fade as a leaf; and our iniquities, like the wind, have taken us away.
Wherefore, as by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death passed upon all men, for that all have sinned.
If we say that we have no sin, we deceive ourselves, and the truth is not in us.

2025-12-10.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You today, acknowledging the truth of Romans 3:23. We confess that we have all sinned and fallen short of Your glory. We have failed to live up to Your righteous standard, and we recognize our need for Your grace and mercy. We are grateful for the sacrifice of Your Son, Jesus Christ, who paid the price for our sins on the cross. Help us to embrace the humility that comes from recognizing our flaws, and to turn away from sin and toward You. Grant us the strength to resist temptation and to live lives that reflect Your glory. Fill us with Your Holy Spirit, that we may walk in Your ways and experience the fullness of Your love. Thank You for Your unwavering love and forgiveness. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-11.versiculo: Luke 14:11 KJV: "For whosoever exalteth himself shall be abased; and he that humbleth himself shall be exalted."
2025-12-11.reflexion: Luke 14:11 provides a powerful lesson on the nature of humility and its ultimate reward. Jesus, in his teachings, consistently challenged the societal norms of his time, particularly the obsession with status and self-importance. This verse encapsulates this challenge, highlighting that those who seek to elevate themselves – those who boast, strive for recognition, and prioritize their own perceived greatness – will ultimately be humbled. Conversely, those who choose humility, those who serve others, acknowledge their limitations, and recognize their dependence on God, will be exalted. This 'exaltation' isn't necessarily about outward success or worldly recognition; it's about finding true value and fulfillment in God's eyes. It’s about experiencing a deep, abiding peace that comes from a life lived in service to others and in humble submission to God's will. The verse isn't just a warning; it's an invitation to embrace humility, not as a weakness, but as the very foundation of true greatness in God's Kingdom. It calls us to re-evaluate our priorities and seek a heart aligned with Christ's own example of selfless service and unwavering humility.

para_meditar.texto: Let nothing be done through strife or vainglory; but in lowliness of mind let each esteem other better than themselves.
When pride cometh, then cometh shame: but with the lowly is wisdom.
Humble yourselves in the sight of the Lord, and he shall lift you up.

2025-12-11.oracion: Heavenly Father, I come before you today acknowledging my need for humility. I confess that I often struggle with pride and the desire for recognition. Forgive me for the times I have sought to exalt myself instead of serving others. Help me to embrace the path of humility, to recognize my dependence on You, and to find my value in You alone. Grant me the grace to serve others selflessly, to be content with obscurity, and to seek Your approval above all else. Give me the strength to resist the temptation of self-promotion and to instead, focus on living a life that reflects Your character. Guide me in every decision, and help me to always remember that true greatness is found in humility. Thank you for your love and your unwavering guidance, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-12.versiculo: 2 Corinthians 4:5 KJV: "For we preach not ourselves, but Christ Jesus the Lord; and ourselves your servants for Jesus' sake."
2025-12-12.reflexion: Today's verse from 2 Corinthians 4:5 reminds us of the core of our calling as believers: to point others to Christ. It's a powerful statement about humility and selflessness. Paul clarifies that our focus shouldn't be on promoting ourselves, our accomplishments, or our personalities. Instead, our primary mission is to preach Jesus Christ as Lord. This means elevating Him in our words, actions, and lives. We are called to be servants, willingly putting aside our own desires for the sake of the Gospel. This doesn't diminish our value, but it reorients our priorities. It highlights that true fulfillment comes from serving others and pointing them to Jesus. It's a constant reminder to check our motives. Are we seeking recognition, or are we genuinely concerned with the spiritual well-being of those around us? This verse calls for a profound shift in perspective, emphasizing that our identity is found in Christ and our purpose is to reflect His glory to the world. It is a call to live a life of service, humility, and unwavering devotion to the Lord Jesus Christ.

para_meditar.texto: Let nothing be done through strife or vainglory; but in lowliness of mind let each esteem other better than themselves.
Then said Jesus unto his disciples, If any man will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow me.
He must increase, but I must decrease.

2025-12-12.oracion: Lord, help me to embrace the message of 2 Corinthians 4:5. Grant me a heart that is humble and a spirit that is focused on You. Remove any desire for self-promotion and fill me with a passion to lift up Jesus in all that I do. Help me to see myself as a servant, always seeking to serve others and point them to You. Give me the grace to prioritize the Gospel above my own desires and ambitions. Teach me to be a vessel of Your love and truth, reflecting Your glory in every interaction. Strengthen my resolve to live a life worthy of the calling I have received, always putting Your name above my own, and seeking to glorify You in all my endeavors. Guide my words and actions, so that they may always point others to the saving grace of Jesus Christ. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-13.versiculo: Romans 14:12 NIV2011: "So then, each of us will give an account of ourselves to God."
2025-12-13.reflexion:
Romans 14:12 offers a stark and sobering truth: accountability. It reminds us that we will each stand before God and give an account of our lives. This isn't a call to fear, but rather a call to intentional living. We are not merely observers in the grand narrative of God's plan; we are active participants. The decisions we make, the words we speak, the actions we take – all will be weighed. 

This verse challenges us to examine our motives. Are we living for the praise of others, or for the glory of God? Are we pursuing our own selfish desires, or are we seeking to serve and love those around us? Accountability to God is not just about avoiding sin; it's about embracing righteousness. It's about striving to live a life that reflects the character of Christ. This perspective should inform our daily choices, from the smallest interactions to the biggest life decisions. It's a call to authenticity, integrity, and a deep understanding of our responsibility as children of God. Consider this not as a burden, but as an opportunity to live a life that pleases Him.

para_meditar.texto: “When the Son of Man comes in his glory, and all the angels with him, he will sit on his glorious throne. All the nations will be gathered before him, and he will separate the people one from another as a shepherd separates the sheep from the goats. He will put the sheep on his right and the goats on his left.”
For we must all appear before the judgment seat of Christ, so that each of us may receive what is due us for the things done while in the body, whether good or bad.
Do not be deceived: God cannot be mocked. A man reaps what he sows.

2025-12-13.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the reminder of our accountability to You. Help us to live each day with the awareness that we will one day stand before Your judgment seat. Grant us the wisdom to discern Your will for our lives and the strength to follow it. Guide us to make choices that honor You in all we do, say, and think. Help us to be mindful of our impact on others and to act with love, compassion, and integrity. Fill us with a spirit of humility and a desire to serve You faithfully, so that when we stand before You, we may hear, 'Well done, good and faithful servant.' We pray for the grace to live a life worthy of Your calling, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-14.versiculo: 1 Timothy 4:7-8 KJV: "But refuse profane and old wives' fables, and exercise thyself rather unto godliness. For bodily exercise profiteth little: but godliness is profitable unto all things, having promise of the life that now is, and of that which is to come."
2025-12-14.reflexion: Today's passage in 1 Timothy 4:7-8 calls us to a vital distinction: the difference between fleeting physical training and the enduring discipline of godliness. Paul urges Timothy to 'refuse profane and old wives' fables' – the empty, distracting narratives that pull us away from truth. Instead, he encourages us to 'exercise thyself rather unto godliness.' This isn't just about outward performance, but the inward transformation of character, rooted in a deep and abiding relationship with God.  The Apostle acknowledges the value of physical exercise; it has its place. However, he clarifies that its benefits are limited, only touching on the temporal. Godliness, on the other hand, yields a profound and lasting profit. It offers promise for both our present life and the life to come. Cultivating a life of godliness involves intentionality: prayer, studying scripture, serving others, and seeking to live in accordance with God's will. It's a daily discipline, a conscious choice to prioritize spiritual growth above all else. It requires us to consistently turn away from the things that distract us and to turn towards the things of God. This commitment to godliness is not a burden, but a pathway to true fulfillment and eternal reward.

para_meditar.texto: Keep thy heart with all diligence; for out of it are the issues of life.
For to be carnally minded is death; but to be spiritually minded is life and peace.
Follow peace with all men, and holiness, without which no man shall see the Lord:

2025-12-14.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the wisdom found in your Word. Help me to recognize the difference between the fleeting benefits of worldly pursuits and the lasting treasures of godliness. Grant me the strength to 'refuse profane and old wives' fables,' those distractions that pull me away from You. Fill my heart with a hunger for Your presence and a desire to live a life that pleases You. Guide me to prioritize spiritual disciplines: prayer, scripture reading, and service to others. Teach me to exercise myself in godliness, that I may experience the fullness of life both now and in eternity. Help me to focus on what truly matters, the things that will last forever. Give me the grace to walk in Your ways and to live a life that reflects Your love and grace, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-15.versiculo: Revelation 1:8 KJV: "I am Alpha and Omega, the beginning and the ending, saith the Lord, which is, and which was, and which is to come, the Almighty."
2025-12-15.reflexion:
Today's verse, Revelation 1:8, is a powerful declaration of God's eternal nature. It introduces us to the Lord, who identifies Himself as the Alpha and Omega, the beginning and the ending. This signifies His completeness, His sovereignty over all things, and His eternal existence. He *is*, *was*, and *is to come*. This transcends our limited understanding of time. He is not bound by the past, present, or future; He encompasses them all. 

The title "Almighty" further emphasizes God's absolute power and authority. He is the all-powerful, all-knowing, and all-present God. This truth should fill us with awe and reverence. Consider the implications: the One who created the universe, who holds all things together, and who governs all events is the same God who loves us and offers us salvation. This passage is a reminder of God's unwavering presence in our lives, offering hope and assurance in a world often filled with uncertainty. It encourages us to trust in His plan and to find our strength in His eternal nature. Let us remember that He is the beginning and the end, the foundation of our faith.

para_meditar.texto: Who hath wrought and done it, calling the generations from the beginning? I the Lord, the first, and with the last; I am he.
Before the mountains were brought forth, or ever thou hadst formed the earth and the world, even from everlasting to everlasting, thou art God.
In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.

2025-12-15.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before You today with hearts full of reverence, acknowledging Your eternal nature. We are humbled by the truth of Revelation 1:8, recognizing that You are the Alpha and Omega, the beginning and the ending. You are the Almighty, and we bow before Your power and majesty. Help us to understand Your eternal plan, to trust in Your unwavering presence, and to find our strength in Your unchanging character. Grant us the wisdom to navigate life's challenges with the assurance that You are always with us, guiding and protecting us. Fill us with Your Holy Spirit, so that we may live each day in accordance with Your will. We praise You for Your love, grace, and faithfulness, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-16.versiculo: Luke 1:37 KJV: "For with God nothing shall be impossible."
2025-12-16.reflexion: Luke 1:37 is a cornerstone of faith, a declaration of the boundless power of God. It's a statement uttered by the angel Gabriel to Mary, assuring her that the seemingly impossible – conceiving a child in her old age – was entirely within God's capabilities. This verse transcends the specific context of Mary's miraculous pregnancy; it speaks to the very nature of God. It reveals a God who is not limited by human constraints, by the laws of nature, or by our own doubts and fears. When we face situations that seem insurmountable – be it a health crisis, a financial struggle, a broken relationship, or a personal failing – Luke 1:37 reminds us that we serve a God who specializes in the impossible. It calls us to embrace faith, to trust in His power, and to believe that He can work even in the most challenging circumstances. The verse encourages us to release our anxieties and place our trust in His divine plan. It is a call to cultivate an unwavering belief that with God, all things are possible. This verse is an invitation to a life lived in expectation of God's miraculous intervention, a life that is rooted in the unwavering belief in His ability to do exceedingly and abundantly above all that we ask or think.

para_meditar.texto: But Jesus beheld them, and said unto them, With men this is impossible; but with God all things are possible.
Behold, I am the Lord, the God of all flesh: is there any thing too hard for me?
I can do all things through Christ which strengtheneth me.

2025-12-16.oracion: Heavenly Father, we come before you today with hearts filled with both hope and humility. We acknowledge our limitations and the challenges that seem impossible to overcome. We are reminded of your infinite power and the truth of Luke 1:37, that nothing is impossible with you. We pray for strength and faith to trust in your divine plan, even when we cannot see the path ahead. Help us to release our anxieties and to believe in your miraculous intervention. Grant us the courage to step out in faith, knowing that you are with us every step of the way. We ask for your guidance, wisdom, and peace as we face our challenges. Let us be a testament to your glory and an example of unwavering faith. We give you all the honor and praise, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-17.versiculo: Philippians 3:7-8 ESV: "But whatever gain I had, I counted as loss for the sake of Christ. Indeed, I count everything as loss because of the surpassing worth of knowing Christ Jesus my Lord. For his sake I have suffered the loss of all things and count them as rubbish, in order that I may gain Christ."
2025-12-17.reflexion: In Philippians 3:7-8, Paul presents a radical perspective on value and loss. He recounts his past achievements, the gains he once held dear, and declares them 'loss' for the sake of Christ. This isn't mere hyperbole; it's a profound spiritual transformation. Paul recognized that the true treasure lies not in earthly accomplishments or religious adherence, but in knowing Jesus Christ. He willingly surrendered everything – his reputation, his status, his comfort – because the surpassing worth of knowing Christ eclipsed all else. This passage challenges us to examine our own priorities. What do we cling to? What do we consider 'gain'? Are we willing to count certain things as loss to gain Christ? This requires a shift in perspective, a willingness to let go of the things that hold us back from a deeper relationship with Him. It's about valuing the eternal over the temporal, the spiritual over the material. Paul's example encourages us to embrace a life of surrender, where Christ becomes the ultimate prize, the source of all our joy and fulfillment. The 'rubbish' he mentions represents anything that hinders our pursuit of Christ, anything that stands between us and a deeper understanding of His love and grace. It's a call to radical commitment, a willingness to sacrifice anything for the sake of knowing Him more fully.

para_meditar.texto: Then Jesus told his disciples, “If anyone would come after me, let him deny himself and take up his cross and follow me.”
For I consider that the sufferings of this present time are not worth comparing with the glory that is to be revealed to us.
looking to Jesus, the founder and perfecter of our faith, who for the joy that was set before him endured the cross, despising the shame, and is seated at the right hand of the throne of God.

2025-12-17.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank you for the example of Paul, who counted everything as loss for the sake of Christ. Help me to see the world through your eyes, to understand the true value of knowing you. Give me the strength to surrender my own desires, my own ambitions, my own attachments, and to embrace the surpassing worth of a life lived in obedience to you. Grant me the courage to count anything as rubbish that keeps me from a deeper relationship with you. Fill me with your Holy Spirit, that I may know you more intimately and love you more completely. Help me to fix my eyes on Jesus, the author and perfecter of my faith, and to walk in His footsteps. Guide me to prioritize the eternal over the temporal, the spiritual over the material. Thank you for your grace, your love, and your constant presence in my life, in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-18.versiculo: 2 Corinthians 4:16-18 NIV2011: "Therefore we do not lose heart. Though outwardly we are wasting away, yet inwardly we are being renewed day by day. For our light and momentary troubles are achieving for us an eternal glory that far outweighs them all. So we fix our eyes not on what is seen, but on what is unseen, since what is seen is temporary, but what is unseen is eternal."
2025-12-18.reflexion: This passage from 2 Corinthians offers a powerful perspective on suffering and the Christian life. It reminds us that our physical bodies may be subject to decay and hardship, but our inner selves are being constantly renewed by the Holy Spirit. Paul encourages us to keep our hearts, understanding that the trials we face are temporary and insignificant compared to the eternal glory God has prepared for us. The key lies in shifting our focus. We are called to fix our eyes, not on the visible struggles of this world, but on the unseen realities of God's kingdom – faith, hope, and the promises of eternal life. This requires a conscious effort to look beyond the immediate circumstances and embrace a perspective rooted in faith. This passage is an invitation to cultivate an eternal mindset, allowing us to find strength and joy even in the face of adversity. It's a call to live with a heart overflowing with hope, knowing that our ultimate reward is far greater than any earthly suffering.

para_meditar.texto: I consider that our present sufferings are not worth comparing with the glory that will be revealed in us.
Now faith is confidence in what we hope for and assurance about what we do not see.
I press on toward the goal to win the prize for which God has called me heavenward in Christ Jesus.

2025-12-18.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the promise of renewal and eternal glory. Help me to not lose heart, even when I face difficulties and challenges. Grant me the strength to fix my eyes on the unseen realities of Your kingdom – Your love, Your faithfulness, and the hope of eternal life. Remind me that the troubles of this world are temporary and that the reward of heaven far outweighs them. Fill me with Your peace and help me to live with an eternal perspective, trusting in Your plan for my life. Give me the wisdom to see beyond the present and to embrace the hope that is found in You. Guide me to renew my faith daily and to find joy in the midst of any circumstance. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-19.versiculo: Ephesians 2:4-5 KJV: "But God, who is rich in mercy, for his great love wherewith he loved us, Even when we were dead in sins, hath quickened us together with Christ, (by grace ye are saved;)"
2025-12-19.reflexion: Today's passage, Ephesians 2:4-5, is a powerful reminder of the immeasurable love and mercy of God. It begins with the transformative word "But," highlighting a dramatic shift from our previous state of spiritual death to the vibrant life we now possess in Christ. The verse emphasizes God's character: He is rich in mercy, and His love is not limited or conditional. It is a "great love" that transcends our failings and shortcomings. This love is the very foundation of our salvation. We were once dead in our sins, separated from God, and without hope. Yet, because of His love, God made us alive together with Christ. This is not something we earned or deserved; it is a gift of grace. The phrase "by grace ye are saved" underscores that salvation is entirely God's initiative, a testament to His boundless compassion. This verse challenges us to reflect on the depth of God’s love and how it has changed our lives. It calls us to gratitude and a renewed commitment to live in the light of this extraordinary grace.

para_meditar.texto: For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.
But God commendeth his love toward us, in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us.
Not by works of righteousness which we have done, but according to his mercy he saved us, by the washing of regeneration, and renewing of the Holy Ghost;

2025-12-19.oracion: Heavenly Father, we are humbled by Your boundless mercy and immeasurable love. Thank You for pursuing us when we were lost and dead in our sins. Thank You for the gift of salvation through Jesus Christ, a gift we did not earn but freely received through Your grace. Help us to understand the depth of Your love, that it may transform our hearts and actions. Grant us a spirit of gratitude, that we may live each day reflecting Your love to others. Help us to share the good news of salvation with those who are still separated from You. May we always remember that our hope is found in You and Your unwavering love. Strengthen our faith and guide us on our journey. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-20.versiculo: Colossians 4:2 KJV: "Continue in prayer, and watch in the same with thanksgiving;"
2025-12-20.reflexion: Today's verse, Colossians 4:2, is a powerful call to action for every believer. It's a simple yet profound command: "Continue in prayer, and watch in the same with thanksgiving." The apostle Paul, writing from prison, knew the importance of these two practices for the spiritual health and resilience of the Colossian church. 'Continue in prayer' is not a suggestion, but a directive. It implies a persistent, ongoing conversation with God. Prayer is the lifeline of our faith, the source of strength, guidance, and comfort in the midst of life's storms. We are to be consistent, unwavering in our communication with Him. The second part of the verse, 'and watch in the same with thanksgiving,' adds another layer of depth. 'Watch' means to be vigilant, alert, and attentive. It urges us to be aware of God's presence in our lives and to be ready to act according to His will. The addition of 'with thanksgiving' transforms our vigilance into an act of joyful gratitude. It reminds us to approach God with a thankful heart, recognizing His blessings and grace in every situation, both good and bad. Thanksgiving is the antidote to complaining, worry, and fear. It cultivates a spirit of contentment and trust, enabling us to persevere in prayer and remain watchful for God's leading. Let us embrace this call to prayer and thanksgiving, allowing it to shape our daily walk and deepen our relationship with our Lord.

para_meditar.texto: Be careful for nothing; but in every thing by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known unto God.
Pray without ceasing.
Enter into his gates with thanksgiving, and into his courts with praise: be thankful unto him, and bless his name.

2025-12-20.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the gift of prayer and the opportunity to come before Your throne. Help me to be a person of consistent prayer, to dedicate time each day to commune with You, sharing my burdens, seeking Your guidance, and expressing my gratitude. Grant me the strength to be watchful, to be aware of Your presence and Your leading in my life. Fill my heart with thanksgiving, that I may see Your blessings in every circumstance and approach each day with a spirit of joy and praise. Help me to overcome worry and fear by casting all my cares on You. Teach me to trust in Your perfect plan and to find peace in Your unwavering love. Guide me to live a life that is pleasing to You. in the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-21.versiculo: Acts 2:21 KJV: "And it shall come to pass, that whosoever shall call on the name of the Lord shall be saved."
2025-12-21.reflexion:
Today's verse, Acts 2:21, offers a powerful and simple truth: salvation is available to all who call upon the name of the Lord. This verse is a cornerstone of the Christian faith, echoing the message of the Gospel from the very beginning. In the context of the early church, Peter, filled with the Holy Spirit, was preaching to a crowd that had been moved by the miraculous events of Pentecost. He explains that the outpouring of the Spirit, the speaking in tongues, and the signs and wonders were a fulfillment of prophecy. He then points directly to the ultimate solution, salvation through faith in Jesus Christ. 

Calling on the name of the Lord isn’t just a verbal exercise; it’s an act of faith, a recognition of our need for a Savior, and a commitment to follow Him. It involves acknowledging Jesus as Lord, repenting of our sins, and turning our lives over to His guidance. This verse emphasizes the accessibility of salvation. It's not limited by ethnicity, social status, or past deeds. The invitation is extended to 'whosoever' – everyone. This promise provides hope and encouragement, reminding us that redemption is within reach for anyone who seeks it with a sincere heart. It's a call to action, a call to turn to Christ and experience the transformative power of His love and grace.

para_meditar.texto: For whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved.
For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.

Wherefore God also hath highly exalted him, and given him a name which is above every name: That at the name of Jesus every knee should bow, of things in heaven, and things in earth, and things under the earth; And that every tongue should confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father.

2025-12-21.oracion: Heavenly Father, thank You for the simple yet profound truth revealed in Acts 2:21. Thank You for extending Your saving grace to all who call upon Your name. Lord, help us to understand the depth of this invitation, to embrace it with faith and to share it with others. Grant us the courage to live a life that reflects our calling, a life of devotion and service to You. Guide us to continually call upon Your name in every aspect of our lives, seeking Your wisdom, strength, and guidance. Strengthen our faith, deepen our relationship with You, and enable us to live in a manner that honors You. We pray for those who have not yet heard the good news, that they may encounter Your love and come to know the salvation offered through Jesus Christ. We commit our lives to You, trusting in Your boundless grace and mercy. In the name of Jesus, amen.

2025-12-22.versiculo: Mark 9:35 NIV2011: "Sitting down, Jesus called the Twelve and said, “Anyone who wants to be first must be the very last, and the servant of all.”"
2025-12-22.reflexion: In a world obsessed with status and recognition, Jesus’ words in Mark 9:35 are a radical call to humility and service. The disciples, like many of us, were caught up in the pursuit of greatness, jostling for position in the kingdom. Jesus, however, turns their understanding upside down. He doesn't promise power and privilege; instead, He demands a life of selflessness. To be first, to be truly great in His eyes, is to become the last, the servant of all. This isn't just a suggestion; it's a fundamental principle of the Christian life. It challenges our innate desire for self-promotion and encourages us to prioritize the needs of others. We are called to lay down our ambitions, our egos, and our desires for personal gain, and instead, embrace a life of humble service. This means actively seeking opportunities to serve those around us, to put others' needs before our own, and to find joy in the act of giving.
